title: Brinksmanship Game
text:
Objective:
This activity is based on the game developed by Phil Haun and Michael O‚ÄôHara to explore decision-making under risk and the dynamics of brinkmanship. The game helps illustrate concepts such as escalation, risk tolerance, and backward induction in strategic situations. It also provides an opportunity to analyze how uncertainty and risk preferences influence negotiation outcomes.
Reference:
Haun, P., & O‚ÄôHara, M. (2022). The Brinkmanship Game: Bargaining Under the Mutual Risk of Escalation. Journal of Political Science Education, 18(3), 379-389. DOI: 10.1080/15512169.2022.2036615

title: Brinksmanship Game
text:
Game Rules:
Setup:
Find a classmate who you haven‚Äôt already interacted with in class.
The game begins with a pot of 10 coins to be divided between the two of you.
Have your notebook or device ready to record the results.
Rounds: The game progresses in rounds where one player decides between splitting the pot or rolling a die. Each round increases the risk of escalation, resulting in both players losing everything.

Round 1: Player 1 chooses between:

Splitting the pot (1 coin for themselves and 9 coins for Player 2).
Rolling the die. If the die roll is 1, escalation occurs, and both players receive 0 coins. If the roll is greater than 1, the game proceeds to Round 2.

Round 2: Player 2 chooses between:

Splitting the pot (8 coins for Player 1 and 2 coins for themselves).
Rolling the die. If the roll is 1 or 2, escalation occurs. If the roll is greater than 2, the game proceeds to Round 3.

Subsequent Rounds: Similar logic follows, with the split amounts changing each round:

Round 3: (3, 7)
Round 4: (6, 4)
Round 5: (5, 5)
Round 6: (4, 6)


The risk of escalation increases in each round. By Round 6, rolling the die becomes extremely risky, with only a 1-in-6 chance of avoiding escalation.
End Conditions:
The game ends if:

Players choose to split the pot in any round.
Escalation occurs after a low die roll.
The sixth round is completed with no escalation.

Dataset Structure
I collected the results from the in-class penalty kicks activity as a csv file where each row represents an different attempted shot.
The columns round, match, and shot contain the id representing which round in the bracket, which match of that specific round, and whether that shot was the first, second, third, fourth, or fifth shot of that match, respectively.
To make these data easier to visualize and calculate statistics, you can import them to an object in R using the read_csv function from the tidyverse package.

  filter(!is.na(s_k), !is.na(s_g)) # filter out missing data

text:
Group Results by Srategy Profile
I might want to compare how often we see a kicker choosing \(Right\) at the same time a goalie blocked \(Right\), vs a kicker chosing \(Right\) when a goalie blocked \(Left\), etc, for all 9 different possible pure strategy combinations.

# summarize by type of strategy profile
profiles_tbl <- data %>%
  group_by(s_k, s_g) %>% # group by each strategy combo to summarise each group
  summarise(
    n = n(), # get counts of each profile
    p = n / N, # calculate proportions of total observations
    num_goals = sum(goal), # count numbers of goals scored
    prob_goal = num_goals / N # probability of goal scored
  ) %>%
  ungroup() # get rid of groups structure to make later manipulations easier
# print the profiles table

Plotting frequency of each strategy profile
If you want a more visual representation of the information in this table, you could use a bar graph where each bar represents a row of the table:

Testing strategy profiles against theory
If you wanted to compare the frequency of each type of choice matchup in this table with what you would expect in an MSNE, you could use the chisq.test function to test the goodness of fit of the n column in our table to some theoretical distribution of p which we would expect for each pure strategy combination.
For example, suppose that a mixed strategy Nash equilibrium of this game would result in each profile being observed with equal probability of 1/9.

# theoretical predictions of each profile being observed
# make sure they're in the same order as in the profiles table

# test whether n is drawn from p_predicted distribution

  x = n_observed,
  p = p_predicted

title: Activity 5 Results
text:
Adjusting Production Quantities
To compare the results across rounds, we could standardize each group‚Äôs production quantity by the theoretical monopolist‚Äôs quantity \(Q_{mp} = \frac{a}{2b}\). This adjustment allows us to evaluate whether groups overproduced or underproduced relative to what they could collectively achieve through collusion.
If instead of a monopoly, several firms were acting competing in an oligopoly, thier individual best-response functions would be:
\[
quantity_i = \frac{a}{2b} - \frac{\sum_{j\neq i}^N quantity_j}{2}
\]
where

\(quantity_i\) is the quantity produced by the single firm \(i\)
\(quantity_j\) are the individual quantities produced by firms besides \(i\)
\(N\) is the total number of firms in the market

One example of an oligopolistic equilibrium would be all competing firms set the same price, in which each firm chooses the individual quantity \(quantity_i^{oligopoly} = \frac{a}{b(N+1)}\).
If firms could cooperate and decide to split the Monopolist‚Äôs quantity amongst each other, where \(quantity_i^{collusion} = \frac{Q_{mp}}{N}\), they would produce fewer ads than in the equilibrium above, and jointly earn higher profit.


See the code
# modify data for plotting
data <- data %>%
  group_by(round) %>%
  mutate(num_firms = sum(!is.na(quantity))) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  # standardize quantity by `a` and `b` of each round
  mutate(
    Q_mp = a/(2*b), # monopolist's quantity
    # equal split of monopoly quantity across all firms
    q_mp = Q_mp / num_firms,
    # divide actual quantities by cooperative quantities
    q_adj = quantity / q_mp
  )

title: Class Activity: Blotto
text:
Objective:
In this activity, you will take on the role of campaign managers for two presidential candidates in the fictional country of Blotto. Your goal is to allocate political resources (ads and canvassers) across three battleground states‚ÄîMontera, Caldeira, and Pacifica‚Äîin a way that maximizes your candidate‚Äôs chances of winning the election.



Montera: The smallest state, meaning it will always receive the least or equal amount of resources.
Caldeira: The second largest state, requiring more resources than Montera but fewer than Pacifica.
Pacifica: The largest state, which will need the most resources to sway voters.




fixed number of political resources across the three states.

Initial Round: Each player must write down three integers in descending order (representing the number of resources spent on Montera, Caldeira, and Pacifica). These integers must sum up to 6.
Reveal: After writing down your numbers, you and your opponent reveal them to each other.
Win Condition: You compare your numbers to your opponent‚Äôs for each state: If your candidate has a higher number of resources than the other player in two or more states, your candidate wins the election. If the numbers are tied in a state, that state is considered a ‚Äúdraw,‚Äù and you only compare the other two.





Allocate Resources: Write three integers that represent how many resources you will allocate to Montera, Caldeira, and Pacifica. These numbers must always follow the rule:

Montera gets the smallest or an equal amount to the other states. Caldeira receives more than or equal to Montera but less than or equal to Pacifica. Pacifica must get the most or equal to Caldeira.

Reveal: Once both players have written their numbers, reveal your allocations.
Compare and Record: Determine the winner by comparing your numbers. Record which player won the majority of states (i.e., who had the higher number of resources in at least two out of three states).





Round 1: Each player allocates 6 total resources.
Round 2: Each player allocates 12 total resources.
Round 3: Choose how many total resources you will allocate (open-ended).
Round 4: Choose how many total resources and and how many battleground states (you don‚Äôt have to adhere to the population ranking).




After completing all rounds, reflect on how changing the number of total resources affected your strategy. Were there certain patterns in how you allocated resources that were more effective? Did your strategy change as the resource pool increased or decreased?



For each round, record the following:

The three numbers you allocated. The three numbers your opponent allocated. The winner of each round (based on the majority of states won).

This activity simulates strategic decision-making in real-world campaigns, where candidates must allocate limited resources effectively to win crucial battlegrounds!
Good luck, candidates!

title: Activity 3: Pirate Treasure
text:
Credit to Dr.¬†Tom Crawford of TomRocksMaths.com. Original post at: https://tomrocksmaths.com/2022/02/10/pirate-game-theory-puzzle/


Five pirates of different heights have a treasure of 100 gold coins, which they plan to share amongst themselves. They decide to split the coins using the following scheme:
The tallest pirate proposes how to share the coins, and ALL pirates (including the tallest) vote for or against it.
If 50% or more of the pirates vote for it, then the coins will be shared that way. Otherwise, the pirate proposing the scheme is thrown overboard, and the process is repeated with the pirates that remain.
Since pirates are generally known to be bloodthirsty, if a pirate will get the same number of coins if voting for or against a proposal, they will choose to vote against so that the proposer is thrown overboard.



For our in-class activity, the class broke up into groups of 4 to 5 people. Each group decided on who would propose first, second, third, ‚Ä¶, last.
* `Round 1 Proposal:` is the distribution proposed by the first pirate 
  for each person at their table to recieve out of the 100 total coins
* `Round 1 Vote:` is the vote by each pirate for that proposed distribution
    * either `yes` or `no`
If the Round 1 Proposal was rejected by more than 50% of pirates, then the game continued until either one pirate‚Äôs proposal was voted for by at least a 50% majority, or until there was only one pirate left.
* `Final Payouts` records the payouts after the last round of play

Course Description
This course introduces the field of game theory, which involves the analysis of strategic situations; where the consequences one person‚Äôs choice depend on the actions of others. The examples of settings we may discuss range from simple games like rock, paper, scissors; to more complicated games of incomplete information in the market for used cars.
We will introduce the general concept of equilibrium and explore the different forms of equilbria in different settings. Students will learn through in-person lectures and discussions, and build their own skills through participation in in-class activities.
This elective is suitable for economics majors and anyone interested in understanding the strategic dynamics that shape our decisions.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Thinking about Randomness
Why should we use mixed strategies?!


As we saw in Activity 2, rarely do real life data fit in completely deterministic models
You can interpret the mixed strategy of one player as the beliefs of other players in equilibrium
Learning some basics of probability theory will help you outside of this class

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Lotteries


In this class, any choices with uncertain payoffs will be called lotteries.
A lottery doesn‚Äôt have to only be about money
For any set of outcomes in a lottery, there will be an associated probability: if \(a\) is a possible outcome, then \(P(a)\) is the probability that it occurs.

All probabilities must be between 0 and 1: \(0 \leq P(a) \leq 1\) for all possibilities \(a\).
Additionally, the probabilities given in a particular lottery must sum to exactly 1: we will assume that one, and exactly one, outcome must actually occur.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Expected Utility


How can you know how much you like a given lottery if you don‚Äôt even know what the outcome will be?
A natural way would be to think of how happy it would make you on average.
The economists‚Äô term for this idea is expected utility or expected payoffs.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Expected Payoffs

You calculate an average by adding up the values of a lottery times the probability of how likely each is.

\[U(a) = \mathbb{E}[u(a)] = \sum_{a}u(a)P(a)\]


This is a weighted average of the payoffs associated with each outcome \(a\), with the weights being the probabilities of each one happening.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text: Double or Nothing ‚Äògame‚Äô

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Expected Payoff Examples
Zoidberg‚Äôs expected payout if he Lets it Ride is \(0.50(\$10) + 0.50(\$0) = \$5 - \$0 = \$5\).


Let‚Äôs face it, Zoidberg always has luck stacked against him, so suppose instead the coin has a 75% probability of tails,
The expected payoff would then be \[0.25(\$10) + 0.75(\$0) = \$2.50 + \$0 = \$2.50 \].

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Cardinal Payoffs

Using expected payoffs implies that the payoffs of the outcomes are cardinal, not merely ordinal: this means that the payoffs can be used not just to rank, but to compare the relative ‚Äúgoodness‚Äù of outcomes.



i.e.¬†an outcome with payoff 2 is actually twice as good as an outcome with payoff 1.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Von-Neumann Morgenstern Utility
There are a few other axioms beyond just completeness and transitivity which are needed when it comes to making rational choices over lotteries.


Continuity: Small changes in lottery probabilities shouldn‚Äôt make your ranking jump around.
Independence: If you know which of two lotteries you prefer, when I add a little bit of another unrelated option into both, it shouldn‚Äôt change your mind.


Because expected utility requires special assumptions beyond those of regular utility, it gets it‚Äôs own special name:
Von-Neumann Morgenstern utility function

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Types of Uncertainty
There are two main types of uncertainty that we‚Äôll cover in this course: external and internal.


External uncertainty results from factors outside of the game that the players don‚Äôt control, such as weather or other random events.
Internal uncertainty result from players‚Äô own actions inside of the game: it is caused whenever a player acts in a random way.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Lotteries

In this class, any choices with uncertain payoffs will be called lotteries.
A lottery doesn‚Äôt have to only be about money
For any set of outcomes in a lottery, there will be an associated probability: if \(a\) is a possible outcome, then \(P(a)\) is the probability that it occurs.

All probabilities must be between 0 and 1: \(0 \leq P(a) \leq 1\) for all possibilities \(a\).
Additionally, the probabilities given in a particular lottery must sum to exactly 1: we will assume that one, and exactly one, outcome must actually occur.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Expected Utility

How can you know how much you like a given lottery if you don‚Äôt even know what the outcome will be?
A natural way would be to think of how happy it would make you on average.
The economists‚Äô term for this idea is expected utility or expected payoffs.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Expected Payoffs

You calculate an average by adding up the values of a lottery times the probability of how likely each is.

\[U(a) = \mathbb{E}[u(a)] = \sum_{a}u(a)P(a)\]

This is a weighted average of the payoffs associated with each outcome \(a\), with the weights being the probabilities of each one happening.

text:
Expected Payoff Examples
Zoidberg‚Äôs expected payout if he Lets it Ride is \(0.50(\$10) + 0.50(\$0) = \$5 - \$0 = \$5\).

Let‚Äôs face it, Zoidberg always has luck stacked against him, so suppose instead the coin has a 75% probability of tails,
The expected payoff would then be \[0.25(\$10) + 0.75(\$0) = \$2.50 + \$0 = \$2.50 \].

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Cardinal Payoffs

Using expected payoffs implies that the payoffs of the outcomes are cardinal, not merely ordinal: this means that the payoffs can be used not just to rank, but to compare the relative ‚Äúgoodness‚Äù of outcomes.


i.e.¬†an outcome with payoff 2 is actually twice as good as an outcome with payoff 1.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Von-Neumann Morgenstern Utility
There are a few other axioms beyond just completeness and transitivity which are needed when it comes to making rational choices over lotteries.

Continuity: Small changes in lottery probabilities shouldn‚Äôt make your ranking jump around.
Independence: If you know which of two lotteries you prefer, when I add a little bit of another unrelated option into both, it shouldn‚Äôt change your mind.

Because expected utility requires special assumptions beyond those of regular utility, it gets it‚Äôs own special name:
Von-Neumann Morgenstern utility function

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Internal Uncertainty

Now that we discussed external uncertainty over states of nature, let‚Äôs talk about internal uncertainty

Internal uncertainty occurs when one or more players pick their strategies randomly.
Picking a strategy at random is really just a different kind of strategy, called a mixed strategy.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Mixed Strategies
When a player always does the same thing, it‚Äôs called a pure strategy
A mixed strategy assigns a probability to each of a player‚Äôs pure strategies.

Like a lottery, the probabilities in a mixed strategy must all be between 0 and 1,
and must sum to exactly 1.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Mixed Strategies

A mixed strategy can assign 0 probability to a pure strategy.
It can even assign probability 1 to a single pure strategy, and probability 0 to all others

this is still, technically, a mixed strategy, but it is a trivial one.
When a player uses a mixed strategy, it turns the other player‚Äôs payoffs into lotteries.

Consider the Deer Hunt:

Suppose that Igg hunts Deer 3/4 of the time, and Rabbit 1/4 of the time.

If Ogg always hunts deer; what is Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff?

Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from playing Deer will be \(0.75(2) + 0.25(0) = 1.5\).

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Mixed Strategies in the Deer Hunt: Generalizing
text:
Mixed Strategies in the Deer Hunt: Generalizing
We can generalize this approach to calculate Ogg‚Äôs expected payoffs from any strategy that Igg chooses to play:

Suppose that Igg plays Deer with probability p, and Rabbit with probability 1 - p.
Then Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from Deer is:

\(2(p) + 0(1 - p) = 2p\), and from Rabbit, it is \(1(p) + 1(1 - p) = 1\).

Note that Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from Deer gets larger with p: the more likely Igg is to hunt Deer, the more attractive an option it becomes for Ogg.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: When to Play a Mixed Strategy?
text:
When to Play a Mixed Strategy?
It‚Äôs possible for a mixed strategy to be a best response to the other player‚Äôs strategy:

if and only if all of the mixed strategy‚Äôs components (pure strategies that are assigned positive probability) are best responses too.
Some intuition: If a strategy is not a best response, you should not play it‚Äîeven as part of a mixed strategy.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: When to play a Mixed Strategy?
text:
When to play a Mixed Strategy?
If a player only has two pure strategies, it becomes simple to tell when a mixed strategy is a best response: the mixed strategy must be a mixture of those two pure strategies, and the only way that both of them are best responses is if they have equal expected payoffs.

Taking the Deer Hunt as an example, the only way that it can be a best response for Ogg to play a mixed strategy is if Deer and Rabbit provide Ogg with equal expected payoffs: we must have \(2p = 1\), or \(p = \frac{1}{2}\).

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
What Mixed Strategy to Play

However, if any mixed strategy is a best response, then all mixed strategies (with the same components) are also best responses.
Intuitively, if the pure strategies going into a mixed strategy are just as good as each other, then it doesn‚Äôt matter what proportions you mix them in.
This means that, while it‚Äôs easy to solve for when it‚Äôs rational for a player to use a mixed strategy, there‚Äôs no way to solve for a particular mixed strategy that the player should play.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Mixed-Strategy Nash Equilibrium
To solve for the Nash equilibria where players are allowed to use mixed strategies: we need to look for the conditions under which a player would be willing to use a mixed strategy.

This means that we‚Äôre going to use one player‚Äôs expected payoffs to solve for the other player‚Äôs mixed strategy

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
MSNE in the Deer Hunt
Let‚Äôs say that Igg plays Deer with probability \(p\) and Rabbit with probability \(1 - p\)
While Ogg plays Deer with probability \(q\) and Rabbit with probability \(1 - q\).

This is simply a framework for describing each player‚Äôs mixed strategies: we‚Äôre using placeholder variables for the players‚Äô mixed strategy probabilities

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
MSNE in the Deer Hunt
We already saw that Ogg‚Äôs expected payoffs from Deer and Rabbit are \(2p\) and \(1\), respectively,
so Ogg would only play a mixed strategy if \(p = \frac{1}{2}\).

Likewise, Igg‚Äôs expected payoffs are \(2q\) and \(1\), and Igg will play a mixed strategy if \(q = \frac{1}{2}\).
The MSNE in this game can be written as: \[ \{(1/2~Deer, 1/2~Rabbit)_{Ogg}, \ (1/2~Deer, 1/2~Rabbit)_{Igg}\}\].

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Error-Checking
Make sure that you‚Äôre setting up the equations used to solve for a player‚Äôs strategy correctly:

Describe when a player is indifferent between their pure strategies:

if you‚Äôre trying to figure out when Player 1 is indifferent, you need to use Player 1‚Äôs payoffs.

However, the probabilities will be based on the other player‚Äôs mixed strategy:

in a game with mixed strategies, the randomness a player deals with is created by the other player‚Äînot themselves.

       & = 3 - q \\
U_1(B) & = 4q + 0(1 - q) \\
       & = 4q \\
U_2(X) & = 2p + 3(1 - p) \\
       & = 2p + 3 - 3p \\
       & = 3 - p \\
U_2(Y) & = 2p + 0(1 - p) \\
       & = 2p
\end{align*}
\]

Based on this, the conditions under which each player will use a mixed strategy are:

3 - q &= 4q & 3 - p &= 2p\\
3 &= 5q & 3 &= 3p\\
q &= 3/5 & p &= 1
\end{align*}
\]

We‚Äôve never seen anything like \(p = 1\) in this context before‚Ä¶
Player 2 will only mix if Player 1 only plays A
This usually occurs when one strategy weakly dominates another.

If you‚Äôve solved for a player‚Äôs mixed strategy and you find that the probability is less than 0, or more than 1:

title: Introduction to Game Theory

Refining Nash Equilibrium

The more you think about it, the less sense this Nash equilibrium makes.

Entrant would stay Out if they really, truly believe that if they Entered, the Incumbent would Fight.
‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs hard to justify that belief when Fighting is costly for the Incumbent.

The Incumbent would have to somehow convince the Entrant that they really would Fight them,

perhaps by making a credible threat.

We will talk more about this kind of strategic move later in the course.
We often don‚Äôt want this kind of Nash Equilibrium. To rule it out, we have the concept of subgame perfection.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Rationality and Subgame Perfection

To justify looking for SPNEs instead of NEs, we assume commonly known sequential rationality.

Players are aware that other players are sequentially rational.
Knowing that other players are sequentially rational, each player can predict the others‚Äô rational behavior and chooses an action with the highest payoff at each of their decision nodes.

Sequentially rational players choose their strategy on the fly, one move at a time, instead of all at once at the beginning of the game.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Finding SPNEs: Backward Induction
The method for finding SPNEs is straightforward‚Äîwe‚Äôve already been using it without spelling it out formally.

Find all the decision nodes in the lowest row (assuming the tree goes top down)
Find the optimal choice at each of these nodes, mark the corresponding branch (or erase/cross out all the other branches).
If you just solved the game‚Äôs initial node, you‚Äôre done!
Otherwise, identify all of the decision nodes in the next row up and return to step 2.

At each step, remember to take into account the optimal moves that you‚Äôve already found lower in the tree.

The Nash equilibrium is based on the idea that every player‚Äôs strategy should be the best response to the strategies of others.

If you can‚Äôt enforce any strategy onto your opponent, you should stick with whatever doesn‚Äôt make you worse off, given what your opponent chose.

title: General Method for Finding Nash Equilibria
text:
The method for finding the Nash equilibrium in a game with continuous strategies is general and applies to many types of games.



Label each player‚Äôs strategy (e.g., \(x\), \(y\), etc.).
Define each player‚Äôs payoff as a function of all players‚Äô strategies.
Maximize each player‚Äôs payoff by choosing their own strategy, holding the others constant.

Question: How does this method apply to real-world competition scenarios?





Suppose we have players 1, 2, and 3, with strategies labeled \(x\), \(y\), and \(z\), and their payoffs \(X\), \(Y\), and \(Z\).
For each player: \[
X = F(x, y, z), \quad Y = G(x, y, z), \quad Z = H(x, y, z)
\]



\(x\) and \(y\) could represent the prices set by two firms, and the functions \(F\) and \(G\) represent their profits.

Question: Why is labeling strategies and payoffs essential for structuring a game?





Each player chooses their strategy to maximize their own payoff, considering the strategies of the others as fixed.
To do this, we take the partial derivative of each player‚Äôs payoff with respect to their own strategy and set it to zero.


For firm 1: \[
\frac{\partial F(x, y, z)}{\partial x} = 0
\]
Question: What does this partial derivative represent in terms of strategy adjustment?





Solve each equation to find the best-response functions. These tell each player the best strategy given what the other players are doing.
For firm 1, the best-response function could look like: \[
x = f(y, z)
\]
This gives the optimal \(x\) for any given values of \(y\) and \(z\).




The Nash equilibrium occurs where all players‚Äô best-response functions intersect. Solve the system of equations: \[
x = f(y, z), \quad y = g(x, z), \quad z = h(x, y)
\]
At this point, no player has an incentive to change their strategy.

The method for finding the Nash equilibrium in a game with continuous strategies is general and applies to many types of games.



Label each player‚Äôs strategy (e.g., \(x\), \(y\), etc.).

\]

Each player chooses their strategy to maximize their own payoff, considering the strategies of the others as fixed.

title: Oligopoly
text:
Some definitions of competition:

Monopoly: A single firm in a market
Oligopoly: Only a few firms

Duopoly: Two firms (like we‚Äôve been looking at)

Perfect Competition: Enough firms to guarantee zero-profit





What would a single firm do in the market?
\[
\Pi = (p-10)(100-p)
\]

Here \(p\) is the only price set by the monopolist










\[
\begin{align*}
  \Pi & = (p-10)(100-p) = 100p - p^2 - 1000 + 10p \\
      & = -p^2 + 110p - 1000
\end{align*}
\]
Find where the slope equals zero: \[
\frac{\delta \Pi}{\delta p} = -2p + 110 + 0
\]
\[
\begin{align*}
  \frac{\delta \Pi}{\delta p} = 0 \\
  \Rightarrow  -2p + 110 & = 0 \\
  110 & = 2p \\
  p = \frac{110}{2} & = 55
\end{align*}
\]









If a single firm:

Price = $55
Profit = $2,025

If two firms competing:

Price = $10
Profit = $0






‚ÄúStore Price Gurantee ‚Äì If you‚Äôre about to buy at a Best Buy store and discover a lower price than ours, let us know and we‚Äôll match that price on the spot.‚Äù


Does this seem like competitive behavior?
Compared to our earlier price competition model,

Will prices be higher
or lower in an equilibrium with price-matching?






Let‚Äôs use the same costs and demand curve.
Two firms; shop 1 and shop 2 who both price match.

If \(p_1\leq p_2\), then shop 1 will sell at \(p_1\)
but if \(p_1 > p_2\), they agree to charge only \(p_2\)





Shop 1‚Äôs payoff function: \[
\begin{equation*}
  \Pi_1 = [\min\{p_1,p_2\}- 10][100 - \min\{p_1,p_2\}](\frac{1}{2})
\end{equation*}
\] Shop 2‚Äôs payoff function: \[
\begin{equation*}
  \Pi_2 = [\min\{p_1,p_2\}- 10][100 - \min\{p_1,p_2\}](\frac{1}{2})
\end{equation*}
\]



Consider both firms charging Monopolist‚Äôs prices of $55:
Is this a Nash?


If \(p_1<55\):

\(\Pi_1(p_1,55) = [p_1 - 10][100 - p_1](\frac{1}{2}) < 2025\)

If \(p_1>55\):

\(\Pi_1(p_1,55) = [55- 10][100 - 55](\frac{1}{2}) 2025\)












With price-matching:

Both firms setting high prices ($55) is stable
Price-matching removes the incentives to undercut prices!
Could be used as a form of legal collusion

text:
Setup: Apple and Samsung‚Äôs Competition
Instead of a symmetric game, let‚Äôs try one with differentiated products
For example, the market for smartphones.
Let‚Äôs assume only two players; A(pple) and S(amsung).

\(D_A(P_A,P_S) = 100 - 2P_A + P_S\)
The higher \(P_A\), fewer iPhones sold
The higher \(P_S\), more people switch from Galaxy to iPhone

title: Introduction to Game Theory
Introduction to Game Theory
Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Step 1: Expand Apple‚Äôs Profit Function
Let‚Äôs expand Apple‚Äôs profit function: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (P_A - 10)(100 - 2P_A + P_S) \\
      & = P_A(100 + P_S - 2P_A) - 10(100 + P_S - 2P_A)
\end{align}
\]

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: Step 2: Simplify the Expanded Profit Function
text:
Step 2: Simplify the Expanded Profit Function
Let‚Äôs expand Apple‚Äôs profit function: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (P_A - 10)(100 - 2P_A + P_S) \\
      & = P_A(100 + P_S - 2P_A) - 10(100 + P_S - 2P_A)
\end{align}
\]
Now, multiply out the terms:
\[
100 P_A + P_A P_S - 2 P_A^2 - 1000 - 10 P_S + 20 P_A
\]
What should we do next to find the best price?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Step 3: Deriving Apple‚Äôs Best-Response Function
To find the best price, we differentiate \(\Pi_A\) with respect to \(P_A\).
Differentiation:
\[
\frac{d\pi_A}{dP_A} = 100 + P_S - 4P_A + 20 = P_S + 120 - 4P_A
\]
Set the derivative equal to zero for maximization: \[
P_S + 120 - 4P_A = 0
\] Solve for \(P_A\): \[
BR_A(P_S) = 30 + 0.25P_S
\]

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
For those without Calculus background
The profit function we wrote out in step 2 seems complicated, so lets simplify it:
\[
\pi_A = - 1000 - 10 P_S +  \mathbf{P_A} (120 + P_S) - 2 \mathbf{P_A}^2
\]
As Apple, we can only set our own price, \(P_A\), everything else we can just treat as a constant
This fits a more general pattern:
\[
S = A + BA - CA^2
\]

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
For those without Calculus background
\[
S = A + BA - CA^2
\]
If we want to find the maximum of \(S\) in this equation as a function of \(A\), as long as \(C>0\), this will take the shape of a parabola with a single peak.

The maxmimum of this function will be reached at:
\(A^* = \frac{B}{2C}\)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
For those without Calculus background
So going back to Apple‚Äôs profit function,

If \(B = 120 + P_S\)
and \(C = 2\)

then applying that the maximum choice will meet \(\frac{B}{2C}\),
we get the same answer of \(P_A^* = 30 + 0.25P_S\)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Step 4: Samsung‚Äôs Best-Response Function
Samsung‚Äôs best-response function is similar:
\[

(strategies for which there is an alternative that is never worse, and sometimes better).






We will not spend a lot of time on this method, because it has two serious flaws:


It is possible for a Nash Equilibrium to involve playing a weakly dominated strategy.


IEWDS may therefore eliminate actual Nash Equilibria.


Unlike IESDS, the order in which you eliminate weakly dominated strategies matters:


you may get different results from different orders of elimination.

Generally speaking, we can eliminate any strategy which is not rational to play in a NE.
It‚Äôs never rational to play strictly dominated strategies, but it‚Äôs sometimes rational to play weakly dominated strategies.
There are other categories of non-rational strategies:
A strategy is a non-best-response or non-rationalizable strategy if and only if, regardless of what the other players choose, it never provides the best possible payoff.
I like to describe non-rationalizable strategies as strategies that you‚Äôd have to be crazy to think were a good idea, i.e.¬†you can‚Äôt rationalize playing them.








Non-rationalizability is very similar to strict dominance, but here‚Äôs the difference:
Strict dominance is pairwise: a strategy \(s\) dominates another, \(s'\), if \(s\) specifically always gives a better payoff than \(s'\).
Non-rationalizability is a property of a single strategy: for a strategy to be non-rationalizable, it means that there is always some option that gives a better payoff‚Äîbut the better option doesn‚Äôt always have to be the same strategy.
To put it another way: strategy \(s\) is not a best response if there is always some strategy* which is better. To be strictly dominated, there must be one particular strategy** which is always better.






In the game below, there are no strictly dominated strategies, meaning that IESDS will not do anything to simplify it.


However, we can see that B is non-rationalizable for Player 1: regardless of whether Player 2 chooses a, b, or c, Player 1 is better off playing either A or C.
Also, b is non-rationalizable for Player 2.












It is not rational to play a non-best-response strategy in a pure-strategy context. (As we‚Äôll see much later, it‚Äôs more complicated in a mixed-strategy context).
Any strictly dominated strategy is also not a best response, but not all NBR strategies are strictly dominated.
Because of this, if we eliminate non-best-responses, using the same steps as IESDS, this process will always eliminate the same strategies, and it may eliminate even more!
This process is, naturally, called Iterative Elimination of Non-Best-Responses (IENBR).






Returning to this same example, we can start by eliminating B.


Once we do this, we can now see that b and c are non-rationalizable, and eliminate them.
Finally, we can see that B is non-rationalizable and eliminate it, leaving only the strategy profile (C, a), which is the Nash equilibrium of this game.

There‚Äôs no guarantee that any particular game will contain strategies that are either strictly dominated or non-rationalizable.
Even when there are strategies we can eliminate, there may not be enough of them to find a NE just by elimination.
So why bother with this?
Even if elimination doesn‚Äôt immediately identify a NE, it can still be helpful to simplify the game before trying other methods.
Simplifying by elimination is especially useful when dealing with mixed strategies‚Äîwhich we‚Äôll get to after the midterm.

title: Dominance
text:
Elimination of dominated strategies can simplify finding equilibria by removing strategies



A dominant strategy is one that performs best no matter what others do.
A strategy is dominated if there is another strategy which is better no matter what the other player does.

Dominated strategies will never by played by a rational agent









When we first discussed NE, we found them by checking all of the strategy profiles in the game to see which of them were stable.
This is easy for a 2x2 game or even a 3x3 game like we‚Äôve seen

but it gets much more time-consuming in games with more players and more strategies per player

We can make it easier to find NEs with a few useful shortcuts








A strategy is said to be strictly dominated if there is some other strategy, in the same player‚Äôs strategy set, which provides that player a higher payoff, no matter what strategies the other players pick.

Another way to phrase it is that a strategy is strictly dominated if some other strategy is a better alternative for the player, no matter what other players do.

text:
When we first discussed NE, we found them by checking all of the strategy profiles in the game to see which of them were stable.
This is easy for a 2x2 game or even a 3x3 game like we‚Äôve seen

but it gets much more time-consuming in games with more players and more strategies per player

We can make it easier to find NEs with a few useful shortcuts

title: Dominance
text:
A strategy is said to be strictly dominated if there is some other strategy, in the same player‚Äôs strategy set, which provides that player a higher payoff, no matter what strategies the other players pick.

Another way to phrase it is that a strategy is strictly dominated if some other strategy is a better alternative for the player, no matter what other players do.

title: Nash Equilibrium
text:
The most basic form of equilibrium in game theory is the Nash Equilibrium (NE), which can be described as:

A strategy profile such that no player can obtain a larger payoff by unilaterally deviating
A strategy profile such that no single player can make themselves better off by changing only their own strategy.
A strategy profile such that, after the game is played, each player is satisfied that they could not have made a better decision











Nash Equilibrium



A list of strategies where each player‚Äôs strategy is the best response to the other‚Äôs best response strategy




In other words, no player has any incentive to deviate in their strategy away from an equilibrium strategy
It is central to the analysis of simultaneous-move games.
Can occur in pure strategies (where players choose a single action) or mixed strategies (randomized choices).

A preemption game is one in which:

players‚Äô payoff increase when they act before others
but their payoffs are also higher when they act later in time



You‚Äôve probably noticed yourself playing a few different preemption games in different settings, even if you didn‚Äôt have a name for it











Here‚Äôs a table to represent the time costs of waiting in that boarding line
Also assume that the benefit to being the first to board is \(30\) and being second is \(20\)

Is the equilibrium outcome of this game a Pareto efficient one?
Why or why not?







A general lesson of all preemption games is that players act too soon from a social efficiency perspective.


Everyone would be better off in the outcome where we all wait, but because there is an incentive to try to jump the line, rational agents cannot be expected to wait instead of getting ahead






Not all games that involve waiting are preemption games, though.

A war of attrition is a type of game where:

Players‚Äô payoffs are higher when they act after other players
and higher the sooner in time they act











What is the rollback equilibrium of this game?







A general lesson of all premption games is that players wait too long than what would be socially efficient if they collectively acted sooner.










What if the players flipped a coin to decide who would act and then that player would immediately act?
What would be their expected payoffs
The problem is that such an agreement is not enforcable

Once the coin flip has been observed, there‚Äôs nothing to stop the player who would be directed to act first to ignore the flip and wait.















What is the rollback equilibrium?
This is a variation of a game called Centipede which comes up a lot in lab experiments

Is this a strategic decision?

No: if it‚Äôs only me

A Tree Graph consists of:

Branches coming from each node which connect it to later nodes
The tree ends in any of the multiple terminal nodes

Each (non-initial) terminal node may have multiple branches leading from it; but must only have one branch that leads to it.




This is because actions are different from strategies

even if the actions are practically similar, it matters how we got there

The game ends with four terminal nodes

Unlike the nodes before, there is no decision to be made because the game is over
By convention, they won‚Äôt be drawn as dots to differentiate them

title: Taxonomy of Games
text:
Sequential or Simultaneous?
Zero-sum or not
Perfect or Imperfect information?

is info symmetric or asymmetric?

One-shot or Repeated?
‚ÄòNoncooperative‚Äô or ‚ÄòCooperative‚Äô?







Sequential Games


players make their moves one after the other
Chapter 3
Visual tool: game trees
Solution Method: backwards induction
Example: Chess



Simultaneous Games


players make their moves at the same time
Chapter 4 & 5
Visual tool: payoff tables
Solution Method: best responses, deletion of dominated strats
Example: Rock, paper, scissors








In sequential games, you have to think about how what you do now will affect what your opponent will do in the future.
. . .

This hierarchy of thinking will make these types of games a little easier for us to think through, so they will be our first category of games.

. . .

We‚Äôll see that sometimes moving first can be adventageous

. . .

While other times it‚Äôs best to wait and see what someone else does





In simultaneous games, you have to figure out what to do now while also thinking about what your opponent is thinking you will do.

title: What is a Game? Definitions
text:
They all involve people making choices which depend on the choices of others
In other words, they are questions of strategy:

Strategic interdependence is present in a social situation when what is best for someone depends on what someone else does. 1









Economics is the study of choice under constraints

We use the term strategy to distinguish socially-dependent choices from simple optimization problems

A game is a type of problem featuring multiple agents, called players,

in which their optimal choice depends on the choices of other players.




In EC311 we look at the consumption choices consumers make when constrained by a budget
In this class, other players set the constraints as well as physical limitations
Think of the toilet paper example: would I want to store a whole garage‚Äôs worth if I wasn‚Äôt worried about everyone else doing the same?






A Game consists of:


a collection of decision-makers, called players;

the set of information available to each player;
the strategies available to each player in each information state;
preferences of the individual players over all possible outcomes

a mapping that tells us how combinations of strategies lead to different outcomes

title: Introduction to Game Theory

Pareto Improvement
The move from a policy y to an alternative policy x is a Pareto improvement if x Pareto dominates y.

Such a policy change should reasonably be seen as unambiguously good
Another perspective is that no-one would veto a pareto improvement

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Pareto Efficiency
An outcome is Pareto Efficient (Optimal) if no other outcome Pareto dominates it.
An outcome is Pareto Infficient if at least one other outcome Pareto dominates it.

Technically rollback solvable, but with \(10^{120}\) possible moves, it hasn‚Äôt been solved by either human or machine
Human experts and computer programs instead rely on experience of past game possibilities

Two participants play this game, taking turns over five rounds.

What explains the drastic departure in lab experiments from the preditiction of backwards induction?

Are players‚Äô not looking ahead to the end of the game?

Maybe? But in that experiment, the percentage of players grabbing increased over later stages. In the 5th node, 73% of player 1‚Äôs grabbed.

Are college students driven by more than money?

Probably. What are some other things which could factor into these participants‚Äô payoffs?
What about how much they care about how much their opponent gets?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Ultimatum Game
Player A and Player B are offered a dollar to divide amongst them.

Player A gets to propose how to split the dollar (i.e., 50:50, 75 to me 25 to you, etc)
Player B can either accept the proposed split, or reject so that both players get nothing


What is the rollback solution if both players payoffs are only determined by how much money they earn?

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Ultimatum Game Evidence
In spite of the theoretical prediction, the most common proposal in lab experiments is 50:50.
Most player B‚Äôs actually reject any offer of 25% or less.

This seems to indicate that most people have some sort of aversion to inequity
If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, behavioral economics develops on the basic rational agent model to make sense of some of these experimental findings

title: Evidence concerning Rollback
text:
One of the goals of game theory is to generate testable predictions

You have all participated in a few such tests of the theory in this class












Did everyone have perfect information about the rules?
Were people thinking ahead?
Were there disagreements within any teams as to the optimal strategy?






What about common knowledge of rationality?


If you were on the second team to choose, and you see the first team doesn‚Äôt take one flag, what should you think?
Should you still stick to the optimal strategy?






This game was relatively simple because it only relied on one team to come up with the optimal strategy


As long as the first team always took the right number of flags, the second team didn‚Äôt have any impact on the game
This is also a zero-sum game, so there were no opportunities for teams to benefit by cooperating
Let‚Äôs look at a similar game, but with non-zero-sum payoffs






Two participants play this game, taking turns over five rounds.
The first is offered a choice between:

splitting 50 cents where they keep 40 and the other player gets 10

or b) they pass the choice to the next player who gets the same choice but the pot they can choose to split from doubles
Now what would you do if you were in this situation?
When would you grab?




What is the theoretical solution?





Out of 100 pairs of your peers, how many times do you think that player 1 would grab in the first node?


In a lab experiment, only 2 times out of 281 did the first player take the first 40 cents (~1%)

How many times do you think player 2 grabed in the second node?

Only 18 out of 279 (~6%) did

How many pairs do you think got to the end of the tree without anyone grabbing? So the last player giving up $12.80 for only $6.40

15%!






What explains the drastic departure in lab experiments from the preditiction of backwards induction?


Are players‚Äô not looking ahead to the end of the game?

Maybe? But in that experiment, the percentage of players grabbing increased over later stages. In the 5th node, 73% of player 1‚Äôs grabbed.

Are college students driven by more than money?

Probably. What are some other things which could factor into these participants‚Äô payoffs?
What about how much they care about how much their opponent gets?







Player A and Player B are offered a dollar to divide amongst them.

Player A gets to propose how to split the dollar (i.e., 50:50, 75 to me 25 to you, etc)
Player B can either accept the proposed split, or reject so that both players get nothing



What is the rollback solution if both players payoffs are only determined by how much money they earn?






In spite of the theoretical prediction, the most common proposal in lab experiments is 50:50.
Most player B‚Äôs actually reject any offer of 25% or less.


This seems to indicate that most people have some sort of aversion to inequity
If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, behavioral economics develops on the basic rational agent model to make sense of some of these experimental findings











What should Jane do if Jon chose \(b\)?
If she knows Jon is rational, then he would choose \(d\) if she chose \(x\), and \(c\) if she chose \(y\)
So Jane should choose \(x\) to get a payoff of \(5\) over \(3\) if she chose \(y\)














But if Jon chose \(b\), doesn‚Äôt that mean that he can‚Äôt be rational?
What should Jane do?
Maybe Jon just made a mistake, and Jane should stick to her assumption that he will continue to try to make rational choices

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
What are Simultaneous-Move Games?

Recall from Chapter 2: Simultaneous games occur when players must move without knowing their rivals‚Äô choices.
This includes cases where decisions are made at different times but without knowledge of others‚Äô decisions.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Real-World Examples

Soccer penalty kick: Striker and goalie must choose directions simultaneously, leading to strategic guessing.
Television manufacturers: Decide on features and pricing without knowing competitors‚Äô decisions.
Voting: Voters cast ballots without knowing others‚Äô choices.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Simultaneous vs Sequential Games


Simultaneous games

neither know the other player‚Äôs actions when they act
graphical representation: game matrix (aka game table, payoff table)
solution method: best response, elimination of dominated strategies
equlibrium concept: nash equilibrium


Sequential games

prior actions are observable to later players
graphical representation: game tree
solution method: backwards induction (aka rollback)
equlibrium concept: subgame perfect nash equilibrium (aka SPNE, rollback equilibrium)

The Strategic Form
A Strategic Form game is defined by:

A set of players who have decisions
A strategy set for each player which is the collection of strategies they choose from
A payoff function which tells us how the player evaluates a strategy profile.

A strategy profile is a combination of strategies made by all players.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Dominance and Strategy Elimination

Elimination of dominated strategies can simplify finding equilibria by removing strategies


A dominant strategy is one that performs best no matter what others do.
A strategy is dominated if there is another strategy which is better no matter what the other player does.

Dominated strategies will never by played by a rational agent

title: Introduction to Game Theory
section: The Problem of Finding Nash Equilibria
text:
The Problem of Finding Nash Equilibria

When we first discussed NE, we found them by checking all of the strategy profiles in the game to see which of them were stable.
This is easy for a 2x2 game or even a 3x3 game like we‚Äôve seen

but it gets much more time-consuming in games with more players and more strategies per player

We can make it easier to find NEs with a few useful shortcuts

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Strict Dominance

A strategy is said to be strictly dominated if there is some other strategy, in the same player‚Äôs strategy set, which provides that player a higher payoff, no matter what strategies the other players pick.

Another way to phrase it is that a strategy is strictly dominated if some other strategy is a better alternative for the player, no matter what other players do.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Finding NEs by Elimination

If all but one of each player‚Äôs strategies can be eliminated like this (leaving only a single strategy profile), then the remaining strategy profile is a NE.

A strictly dominated strategy can never be part of a NE.

However, it‚Äôs rare that a player has one strategy which strictly dominates all of their others from the very start, as in the Prisoner‚Äôs Dilemma. (This is called a strictly dominant strategy.)
Even if a player doesn‚Äôt have a strictly dominant strategy, we can still sometimes use elimination to find a NE, by using a process called Iterated Elimination of Strictly Dominated Strategies (IESDS).

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Common Knowledge of Rationality

Let‚Äôs assume that, not only is every player rational, they all know that the other players are rational too.
This means that players can deduce which strategies the other players would never play.
And if a player can eliminate another player‚Äôs strategy, it may reveal additional strictly dominated strategies that can be eliminated.

The process of IESDS can be summed up in three steps:

Search for a strictly dominated strategy belonging to any player. If none exists, stop here: IESDS is completed.
Eliminate (cross out) that strategy. Optionally, re-draw the game table without the eliminated strategy.
Return to step 1.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Nash Equilibrium
The most basic form of equilibrium in game theory is the Nash Equilibrium (NE), which can be described as:

A strategy profile such that no player can obtain a larger payoff by unilaterally deviating
A strategy profile such that no single player can make themselves better off by changing only their own strategy.
A strategy profile such that, after the game is played, each player is satisfied that they could not have made a better decision

Can occur in pure strategies (where players choose a single action) or mixed strategies (randomized choices).

Nash equilibrium assumes:

Players are uncertain about others‚Äô choices but form subjective beliefs about them.
These beliefs are central to decision-making in Nash equilibrium.
The equilibrium is found when every player‚Äôs belief about others‚Äô actions is correct, and their response to these beliefs is optimal.

Best-Responding

In finding Nash equilibrium, best-response analysis is key.
Each player chooses their best action in response to the strategies of others.
This iterative process helps in solving games with many possible strategies.

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Best Responses

If you know other player‚Äôs strategy, then you can respond accordingly
Even if you don‚Äôt know, forming a belief helps you solve the game








Best Response Definition


Strategy \(s_i\) is a best response to \(s_{-i}\) if and only if it provides the highest payoff possible when the other player chooses \(s_{-i}\).

The best response correspondence \(b_i(s_{-i})\) is the strategy or set of strategies that give the highest payoff against \(s_{-i}\)

title: Introduction to Game Theory
text:
Some Notes on Best Responses

‚Äúto another player‚Äôs strategy‚Äù is important.
A strategy can only be a best response to some strategy of the other player.

No such thing as a universally best response (that‚Äôs a dominant strategy)

There is always at least one best response to another player‚Äôs strategy

And there may be multiple best responses to another players strategy

title: Simultaneous-Move Games
text:
Recall from Chapter 2: Simultaneous games occur when players must move without knowing their rivals‚Äô choices.
This includes cases where decisions are made at different times but without knowledge of others‚Äô decisions.








Soccer penalty kick: Striker and goalie must choose directions simultaneously, leading to strategic guessing.
Television manufacturers: Decide on features and pricing without knowing competitors‚Äô decisions.
Voting: Voters cast ballots without knowing others‚Äô choices.









Simultaneous games

neither know the other player‚Äôs actions when they act
graphical representation: game matrix (aka game table, payoff table)
solution method: best response, elimination of dominated strategies
equlibrium concept: nash equilibrium




Sequential games

prior actions are observable to later players
graphical representation: game tree
solution method: backwards induction (aka rollback)
equlibrium concept: subgame perfect nash equilibrium (aka SPNE, rollback equilibrium)








A Strategic Form game is defined by:

A set of players who have decisions
A strategy set for each player which is the collection of strategies they choose from
A payoff function which tells us how the player evaluates a strategy profile.

A strategy profile is a combination of strategies made by all players.

title: Prisoners‚Äô Dilemma
text:
To see the concept of Nash Equilibrium in action, we will start with the most famous example.



There are two criminals, who I like to call Guido and Luca.


Guido and Luca have each committed murder, but the police have no way of proving it.
However, the police can prove that they have lied on their taxes, which is a much lesser offense.
The police get Guido and Luca into separate rooms so that they can‚Äôt talk, and offer them a choice: Testify against the other, or stay Quiet.
If they Testify, they will receive lenient sentencing, and the police will be able to convict the other criminal.






There are four different possibilities of what could happen:


Both Keep Quiet: Police can only convict them of tax fraud, so Guido and Luca only serve 1 year in prison each
Guido Testifies, but Luca Keeps Quiet: Guido gets 0 prison time for cooperating, Guido gets hit with a full 20 year sentence
Luca Testifies, but Guido Keeps Quiet: Luca gets 0 prison time, Luca gets hit with a full 20 year sentence
Both Testify: Both get convicted of murder, but get their prison sentences reduced to 10 years each because they cooperated

Remember that you cannot communicate with your fellow prisoner
How would you have to be that they won‚Äôt sell you out for you to choose to keep quiet?






Let‚Äôs think through this from Guido‚Äôs perspective.

Imagine that Luca keeps Quiet. This gives Guido a choice of two options: he can also keep Quiet, and get a short prison sentence, or he can Testify and get released. Obviously, Guido prefers to Testify.
Now imagine that Luca Testifies. This again gives Guido a choice of two options: he can also keep Quiet, and get a long prison sentence, or he can Testify and get a medium sentence. Obviously, Guido still prefers to Testify.
In other words, Guido prefers to Testify, no matter what Luca does.
If we go through this logic from Luca‚Äôs perspective, we find that Luca also always prefers to Testify.






Although the outcome where both criminals keep quiet Pareto dominates the outcome where they both testify and serve 10 years, would it be stable?

In the {Quiet, Quiet} strategy profile, either player could deviate to Testify and shorten their prison time.
{Testify, Testify} is the only stable strategy profile, where no one could unilaterally deviate to decrease their sentence.






So, if Guido and Luca each act in their own self-interest, they will wind up each getting a medium prison sentence.
This is despite the fact that, if they both kept Quiet, they could each get a short prison sentence instead.

title: Best-Response Analysis
text:
Not every game is dominance solvable through IESDS.
Can we still find NE in those games?


Yes! We just need to remember the best-responding part of our definition of NE








In finding Nash equilibrium, best-response analysis is key.
Each player chooses their best action in response to the strategies of others.
This iterative process helps in solving games with many possible strategies.








If you know other player‚Äôs strategy, then you can respond accordingly
Even if you don‚Äôt know, forming a belief helps you solve the game


. . .






Best Response Definition



Strategy \(s_i\) is a best response to \(s_{-i}\) if and only if it provides the highest payoff possible when the other player chooses \(s_{-i}\).

The best response correspondence \(b_i(s_{-i})\) is the strategy or set of strategies that give the highest payoff against \(s_{-i}\)









‚Äúto another player‚Äôs strategy‚Äù is important.
A strategy can only be a best response to some strategy of the other player.

No such thing as a universally best response (that‚Äôs a dominant strategy)

There is always at least one best response to another player‚Äôs strategy

And there may be multiple best responses to another players strategy







Marking best responses in normal form:


Go through each strategy in the game of one player (row or column)

Mark the best option of the responding player
Okay to mark the payoffs, but keep in mind they are not same as the strategies

Don‚Äôt try to describe the best response using the payoff.

A best response is a strategy

Finding best responses first makes it a lot easier to search for non-rationalizable strategies.
Recall that a non-rationalizable strategy can also be called a non-best response: if none of the payoffs of a strategy are marked to indicate that it is a best-response, it is non-rationalizable. In other words:

Any column in which none of Player 2‚Äôs payoffs are marked to indicate a best response, is non-rationalizable.

title: Political Campaign Advertising
text:
Two political parties, L and R, are competing in an election by spending money on campaign advertising.



Vote shares depend on each party‚Äôs advertising:

If party L spends \(x\) million dollars and party R spends \(y\) million dollars:

Party L‚Äôs vote share is \(\frac{x}{x + y}\)
Party R‚Äôs vote share is \(\frac{y}{x + y}\)



Question: How might spending more on ads increase one party‚Äôs vote share?





Each party‚Äôs payoff is its vote share minus the cost of its advertising.

L‚Äôs payoff: \[
100 \times \frac{x}{x + y} - x
\]
R‚Äôs payoff: \[
100 \times \frac{y}{x + y} - y
\]





To find the best-response functions for each party, we use calculus.



Differentiate R‚Äôs payoff with respect to \(y\): \[
\frac{d}{dy} \left( 100 \times \frac{y}{x + y} - y \right) = 0
\]
Simplifying: \[
100 \times \frac{x}{(x + y)^2} = 1
\]
This gives R‚Äôs best-response function: \[
y = 10 \sqrt{x} - x
\]






By symmetry, Party L‚Äôs best-response function is: \[
x = 10 \sqrt{y} - y
\]
Question: How do you think these best-response functions help us find the Nash equilibrium?




We solve for \(x\) and \(y\) by substituting the best-response functions into each other.

From \(y = 10 \sqrt{x} - x\), substitute into L‚Äôs equation: \[
x = 10 \sqrt{10 \sqrt{x} - x} - (10 \sqrt{x} - x)
\] Solve this system to find \(x = y = 25\).

Question: What does this tell us about each party‚Äôs optimal spending?








At equilibrium: - Both parties spend $25 million on ads. - Neither party can improve its vote share by changing its spending.



In this case, both parties overspend compared to the social optimum. This situation is similar to a prisoner‚Äôs dilemma.






In the prisoner‚Äôs dilemma structure, both parties would be better off if they reduced their advertising spending, saving money without losing votes.
Question: Why don‚Äôt the parties naturally reduce their spending to reach this optimal outcome?




What if one party has an advantage, such as lower advertising costs or more effective ads?

If Party R‚Äôs advertising dollars are twice as effective, its best-response curve shifts upwards, and it spends more than L.

Question: How might this advantage affect the equilibrium?





Political campaigns can be viewed as strategic games where each party competes for votes through advertising.
While competition leads to higher spending, the results resemble a prisoner‚Äôs dilemma, where both parties might benefit from cooperation.





What if: - There are three competing political parties? - Or one party has access to a significantly larger budget?
Discuss with your peers how this might change the outcome of the advertising game.

title: Price Competition with Differentiated Products
text:
Instead of a symmetric game, let‚Äôs try one with differentiated products
For example, the market for smartphones.
Let‚Äôs assume only two players; A(pple) and S(amsung).

\(D_A(P_A,P_S) = 100 - 2P_A + P_S\)
The higher \(P_A\), fewer iPhones sold
The higher \(P_S\), more people switch from Galaxy to iPhone





Tim Cook‚Äôs profit based on his price and number of iPhone customers: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (\text{price} - \text{cost})(\textbf{quantity sold}) \\
      & = (P_A - 10)\mathbf{(100 - 2P_A + P_S)}
\end{align}
\]
Assume a marginal cost of 10 per unit for iPhones




Samsung‚Äôs profit based on prices and number of Galaxys sold: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_S & = (P_S - 30)\mathbf{(100 - 2P_S + P_A)}
\end{align}
\]
Assume Samsung has a higher cost of 30 per Galaxy produced




Let‚Äôs expand Apple‚Äôs profit function: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (P_A - 10)(100 - 2P_A + P_S) \\
      & = P_A(100 + P_S - 2P_A) - 10(100 + P_S - 2P_A)
\end{align}
\]




Let‚Äôs expand Apple‚Äôs profit function: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (P_A - 10)(100 - 2P_A + P_S) \\
      & = P_A(100 + P_S - 2P_A) - 10(100 + P_S - 2P_A)
\end{align}
\]
Now, multiply out the terms:
\[
100 P_A + P_A P_S - 2 P_A^2 - 1000 - 10 P_S + 20 P_A
\]
What should we do next to find the best price?




To find the best price, we differentiate \(\Pi_A\) with respect to \(P_A\).


\[
\frac{d\pi_A}{dP_A} = 100 + P_S - 4P_A + 20 = P_S + 120 - 4P_A
\]
Set the derivative equal to zero for maximization: \[
P_S + 120 - 4P_A = 0
\] Solve for \(P_A\): \[
BR_A(P_S) = 30 + 0.25P_S
\]





The profit function we wrote out in step 2 seems complicated, so lets simplify it:
\[
\pi_A = - 1000 - 10 P_S +  \mathbf{P_A} (120 + P_S) - 2 \mathbf{P_A}^2
\]
As Apple, we can only set our own price, \(P_A\), everything else we can just treat as a constant
This fits a more general pattern:
\[
S = A + BA - CA^2
\]




\[
S = A + BA - CA^2
\]
If we want to find the maximum of \(S\) in this equation as a function of \(A\), as long as \(C>0\), this will take the shape of a parabola with a single peak.


The maxmimum of this function will be reached at:
\(A^* = \frac{B}{2C}\)






So going back to Apple‚Äôs profit function,

If \(B = 120 + P_S\)
and \(C = 2\)

then applying that the maximum choice will meet \(\frac{B}{2C}\),
we get the same answer of \(P_A^* = 30 + 0.25P_S\)



Samsung‚Äôs best-response function is similar:
\[
\begin{align}
\pi_A & = (P_S - 30)(100 - 2P_S + P_A) \\
      & = 100P_S - 2P_S^2 + P_A P_S - 3000 + 60P_S - 30P_A
\end{align}
\]
\[
\begin{align*}
\frac{d\pi_S}{dP_S} & = 0 \\
100 - 4P_S + P_A + 60 & = 0 \\
BR_S(P_A) & = 40 + .25P_A
\end{align*}
\]




We have one best response rule for each player

as a function of the other player‚Äôs pricing strategy

I.e., a system of two equations and two unknowns







A Nash is a stable configuration of strategies

in which each player is best responding to the other



When each player is setting profit-maximizing price

conditional on the other player‚Äôs price,
there will be no incentive to change price

Plug in one player‚Äôs best response rule into the other player‚Äôs best response rule

to solve for the equilibrium price






We solve the system of equations for \(P_A\) and \(P_S\): \[
P_A = 30 + 0.25P_S
\] \[
P_S = 40 + 0.25P_A
\]




Substitute one equation into the other: \[
P_A = 30 + 0.25(40 + 0.25P_S)
\] Simplify: \[
P_A = 30 + 10 + 0.0625P_A
\] Solve for \(P_S\): \[
\begin{align*}
  P_A(1-0.0625) & = 40 \\
  P_S & = 42.67
\end{align*}
\]
Then, plug \(P_S = 20\) back into the first equation: \[
P_S = 40 + 0.25(42.67) = 50.67
\]




At equilibrium:

\(P_A = 42.67\), \(P_S = 50.67\)
Do either firm have an incentive to deviate?

How would we check?












Step 1: Expand the profit function.
Step 2: Simplify the expanded equation.
Step 3: Differentiate and solve for best-response.
Step 4: Repeat for Samsung.
Step 5: Solve for Nash equilibrium.

title: Cournot Duopoly
text:
In the sandwich shop game, both players set prices

We call that a Bertrand model of oligopoly

We could also imagine firms choosing quantities

We‚Äôll call this the Cournot model







First of all, we need payoff functions for each player.
Since the players are firms, and the goal of a firm is to maximize profit, we‚Äôll use the firms‚Äô profits as their payoffs.
We can construct the profit functions by taking TR - TC, or in this case, Pq - c(q).
Solving for P, we find that \(P = 100 - Q = 100 - q_1 - q_2\).






This gives us: \[
\begin{align}
\pi_1 &= (100 - q_1 - q_2)q_1 - 10q_1 & \pi_2 &= (100 - q_1 - q_2)q_2 - 10q_2\\
&= 100q_1 - q_1^2 - q_1q_2 - 10q_1 & &= 100q_2 - q_1q_2 - q_2^2 - 10q_2\\
&= 90q_1 - q_1^2 - q_1q_2 & &= 90q_2 - q_1q_2 - q_2^2\\
&= (90 - q_2)q_1 - q_1^2 & &= (90 - q_1)q_2 - q_2^2
\end{align}
\] ‚Äî



These best-response functions are in the by-now familiar quadratic form. Both of them have negative squared terms, so we can look for a maximum: \[
\begin{align}
q_1 &= \frac{-(90 - q_2)}{2(-1)} & q_2 &= \frac{-(90 - q_1)}{2(-1)}\\
&= \frac{90 - q_2}{2} & &= \frac{90 - q_1}{2}\\
&= 45 - \frac{q_2}{2} & &= 45 - \frac{q_1}{2}
\end{align}
\] ‚Äî



Solve these best-response rules as a system of equations: \[
\begin{align}
q_1 &= 45 - \frac{1}{2}q_2\\
q_2 &= 45 - \frac{1}{2}q_1\\
\implies q_1 &= 45 - \frac{1}{2}(45 - \frac{1}{2}q_1) & q_2 &= 45 - \frac{1}{2}(30)\\
q_1 &= 45 - \frac{45}{2} + \frac{1}{4}q_1 & &= 45 - 15\\
\frac{3}{4}q_1 &= \frac{45}{2} & q_2^* &= \boxed{30}\\
q_1^* &= \boxed{30}
\end{align}
\]





In an oligopoly:

Firms‚Äô prices (quantities) are interdependent.
The best-response functions allow us to determine equilibrium prices (or quantities in Bertrand).

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Refining Nash Equilibrium


The more you think about it, the less sense this Nash equilibrium makes.

Entrant would stay Out if they really, truly believe that if they Entered, the Incumbent would Fight.
‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs hard to justify that belief when Fighting is costly for the Incumbent.

The Incumbent would have to somehow convince the Entrant that they really would Fight them,

perhaps by making a credible threat.

We will talk more about this kind of strategic move later in the course.
We often don‚Äôt want this kind of Nash Equilibrium. To rule it out, we have the concept of subgame perfection.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Subgames


A subgame is a subset of an extensive-form game which, itself, is a complete game.
A subgame is a single node, and all of the branches and nodes descending from it,

so it forms a complete game by itself

A game is, technically, a subgame of itself, but it is an improper subgame.

(Any subgames other than the entire game are proper subgames.)

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Subgame Perfection
So why do we care about subgames?


subgame-perfect Nash equilibrium (aka SPNE), that does not produce the questionable equilibria we saw earlier.
All SPNE are also regular Nash equilibria.
But unique to SPNE, they have to also produce a Nash equilibrium in every subgame

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
SPNE in the Entry Game





There is only a single proper subgame in the Entry Game.
A SPNE of this game must have a NE in that subgame.
The only NE of the subgame is for the Incumbent to Accommodate.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
SPNE in the Entry Game






Given that the Incumbent Accommodates, the Entrant now faces a choice between staying Out, or Entering and being Accommodated.
The Entrant‚Äôs best response is to Enter, and the SPNE is (Enter, Accommodate)

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Rationality and Subgame Perfection


To justify looking for SPNEs instead of NEs, we assume commonly known sequential rationality.

Players are aware that other players are sequentially rational.
Knowing that other players are sequentially rational, each player can predict the others‚Äô rational behavior and chooses an action with the highest payoff at each of their decision nodes.

Sequentially rational players choose their strategy on the fly, one move at a time, instead of all at once at the beginning of the game.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Finding SPNEs: Backward Induction
The method for finding SPNEs is straightforward‚Äîwe‚Äôve already been using it without spelling it out formally.


Find all the decision nodes in the lowest row (assuming the tree goes top down)
Find the optimal choice at each of these nodes, mark the corresponding branch (or erase/cross out all the other branches).
If you just solved the game‚Äôs initial node, you‚Äôre done!
Otherwise, identify all of the decision nodes in the next row up and return to step 2.

At each step, remember to take into account the optimal moves that you‚Äôve already found lower in the tree.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Mixed Strategies
When a player always does the same thing, it‚Äôs called a pure strategy
A mixed strategy assigns a probability to each of a player‚Äôs pure strategies.


Like a lottery, the probabilities in a mixed strategy must all be between 0 and 1,
and must sum to exactly 1.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Mixed Strategies


A mixed strategy can assign 0 probability to a pure strategy.
It can even assign probability 1 to a single pure strategy, and probability 0 to all others

this is still, technically, a mixed strategy, but it is a trivial one.
When a player uses a mixed strategy, it turns the other player‚Äôs payoffs into lotteries.

Consider the Deer Hunt:

Suppose that Igg hunts Deer 3/4 of the time, and Rabbit 1/4 of the time.


If Ogg always hunts deer; what is Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff?

Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from playing Deer will be \(0.75(2) + 0.25(0) = 1.5\).

title: EC327 Game Theory
section: Mixed Strategies in the Deer Hunt: Generalizing
text:
Mixed Strategies in the Deer Hunt: Generalizing
We can generalize this approach to calculate Ogg‚Äôs expected payoffs from any strategy that Igg chooses to play:


Suppose that Igg plays Deer with probability p, and Rabbit with probability 1 - p.
Then Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from Deer is:

\(2(p) + 0(1 - p) = 2p\), and from Rabbit, it is \(1(p) + 1(1 - p) = 1\).

Note that Ogg‚Äôs expected payoff from Deer gets larger with p: the more likely Igg is to hunt Deer, the more attractive an option it becomes for Ogg.

title: EC327 Game Theory
section: When to Play a Mixed Strategy?
text:
When to Play a Mixed Strategy?
It‚Äôs possible for a mixed strategy to be a best response to the other player‚Äôs strategy:

if and only if all of the mixed strategy‚Äôs components (pure strategies that are assigned positive probability) are best responses too.
Some intuition: If a strategy is not a best response, you should not play it‚Äîeven as part of a mixed strategy.

title: EC327 Game Theory
section: When to play a Mixed Strategy?
text:
When to play a Mixed Strategy?
If a player only has two pure strategies, it becomes simple to tell when a mixed strategy is a best response: the mixed strategy must be a mixture of those two pure strategies, and the only way that both of them are best responses is if they have equal expected payoffs.


Taking the Deer Hunt as an example, the only way that it can be a best response for Ogg to play a mixed strategy is if Deer and Rabbit provide Ogg with equal expected payoffs: we must have \(2p = 1\), or \(p = \frac{1}{2}\).

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
What Mixed Strategy to Play


However, if any mixed strategy is a best response, then all mixed strategies (with the same components) are also best responses.
Intuitively, if the pure strategies going into a mixed strategy are just as good as each other, then it doesn‚Äôt matter what proportions you mix them in.
This means that, while it‚Äôs easy to solve for when it‚Äôs rational for a player to use a mixed strategy, there‚Äôs no way to solve for a particular mixed strategy that the player should play.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Mixed-Strategy Nash Equilibrium
To solve for the Nash equilibria where players are allowed to use mixed strategies: we need to look for the conditions under which a player would be willing to use a mixed strategy.


This means that we‚Äôre going to use one player‚Äôs expected payoffs to solve for the other player‚Äôs mixed strategy

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
MSNE in the Deer Hunt
Let‚Äôs say that Igg plays Deer with probability \(p\) and Rabbit with probability \(1 - p\)
While Ogg plays Deer with probability \(q\) and Rabbit with probability \(1 - q\).


This is simply a framework for describing each player‚Äôs mixed strategies: we‚Äôre using placeholder variables for the players‚Äô mixed strategy probabilities

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
MSNE in the Deer Hunt
We already saw that Ogg‚Äôs expected payoffs from Deer and Rabbit are \(2p\) and \(1\), respectively,
so Ogg would only play a mixed strategy if \(p = \frac{1}{2}\).


Likewise, Igg‚Äôs expected payoffs are \(2q\) and \(1\), and Igg will play a mixed strategy if \(q = \frac{1}{2}\).
The MSNE in this game can be written as: \[ \{(1/2~Deer, 1/2~Rabbit)_{Ogg}, \ (1/2~Deer, 1/2~Rabbit)_{Igg}\}\].

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Error-Checking
Make sure that you‚Äôre setting up the equations used to solve for a player‚Äôs strategy correctly:


Describe when a player is indifferent between their pure strategies:

if you‚Äôre trying to figure out when Player 1 is indifferent, you need to use Player 1‚Äôs payoffs.

However, the probabilities will be based on the other player‚Äôs mixed strategy:

in a game with mixed strategies, the randomness a player deals with is created by the other player‚Äînot themselves.

Suppose in MSNE that Player 1 plays a (non-trivial) mixed strategy.
Then Player 2 must also play a mixed strategy, in which q = 3/5.

But Player 2 will only mix if Player 1 plays p = 1, which is a trivial mixed strategy.
This is a contradiction, there is no MSNE where Player 1 plays a non-trivial mixed strategy

Suppose Player 2 plays a non-trivial mixed strategy.


Then Player 1 must play A as a pure strategy.
Player 2 will play A if \(3 - q \geq 4q\), i.e.¬†if \(3/5 \geq q\).
This lets Player 2 play a non-trivial mixed strategy! There is no contradiction here.

title: EC327 Game Theory
text:
Multiple MSNE in one game


There are a range of MSNEs here: all strategy profiles \((1, 0), (q, 1 - q)\), in which \(q \in (0, 3/5]\)
There are also two trivial MSNEs, \((1, 0), (0, 1)\) and \((0, 1), (1, 0)\), which are really just the pure-strategy Nash equilibria (A, Y) and (B, X) expressed in the form of an MSNE.
